div.p: This paper studies optimal tracking and regulation control problems, in which objective functions of tracking error and regulated response, defined by integral square measures, are to be minimized jointly with the control effort, where the latter is measured by the plant input energy. Our primary objective in this work is to search for fundamental design limitations beyond those known to be imposed by nonminimum phase zeros, unstable poles, and time delays. For this purpose, we solve the problems explicitly by deriving analytical expressions for the best achievable performance. It is found that this performance limit depends not only on the plant nonminimum phase zeros, time delays, and unstable poles-a fact known previously-but also on the plant gain in the entire frequency range. The results thus reveal and quantify another source of fundamental performance limitations beyond those already known, which are nonexistent when only conventional performance objectives such as tracking and regulation are addressed without taking into account the control energy constraint. Among other things, they exhibit how the lightly damped poles, the anti-resonant zeros, as well as the bandwidth of the plant may affect the performance.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: I N RECENT years, there has been growing attention devoted to the studies of intrinsic performance limits achievable by feedback control (see, e.g., [21], [4], and the references therein). In these studies, it has been customary to examine certain classical optimal control problems under optimality criteria formulated in time or frequency domain [17], [19], [6], [22], [18], which have led to explicit expressions of the best achievable performance. Two of such well-studied problems are the optimal reference tracking and optimal regulation problems [6], [18], [22]. It has been known that the minimal tracking error depends upon the nonminimum phase zeros and time delays in the plant, while the minimal regulation energy depends upon the plant unstable poles. These results, together with Bode and Poisson integral relations which form another branch of performance studies [8], [16], [1], [11], [2]- [4], reveal that in one way or another the performance of feedback systems is fundamentally constrained by the nonminimum phase zeros, unstable poles, and time delays in the plant.

It should be recognized, nevertheless, that the performance criteria alluded to beforehand are highly idealistic, and thus serve more appropriately as an ideal, theoretical bound. Indeed, in the optimal tracking problem, in order to attain the minimal tracking error, the input to the plant is often required to have an infinite energy. This, of course, is seldom possible in practice, and in a more realistic setting, the input must be constrained in magnitude or energy. This consideration leads us to reexamine the tracking problem, to study the best tracking accuracy achievable when only finite input energy is available. More specifically, we consider an optimal tracking control problem in which not only the step error response, but also the plant input energy, both quantified under a square-integral or an measure, is penalized. It is worth noting that such a performance objective, albeit a standard one in optimal control, has been investigated mainly in the so-called cheap control strategy [14], [19], [21], that is, in the limit when the control penalty vanishes. In the present formulation, the control effort is fixed instead of being "cheap." This effectively restrains the control effort, defined as the energy of the control input.

Optimal tracking with finite control energy is just one case of many design objectives which seek to constrain the control effort explicitly. Another example of primary interest in this paper is the problem of optimal regulation under control effort constraint. In this classical optimal control problem, the output response due to a nonzero initial condition is to be restored to zero. We seek to accomplish this while minimizing jointly the output response and the control energy under the objective. Additionally, we also study some related constrained optimization problems which seek to constrain rather than penalize the control effort. It is worth emphasizing that both the tracking and regulation problems under consideration, whether the control energy is a control objective or a constraint, are all dual objective optimal control problems, in which a predominant concern lies in the control effort. In the optimal control framework, they amount to the so-called "two-block" problems. With this defining feature, the control objectives take into account the system's properties at both the plant input and output, which in general may vary widely, a fact perceived as a main source of control design difficulty for multivariable systems [9]. More generally, both problems may be viewed as certain special cases of the general optimal disturbance attenuation problem, where the disturbance signal may enter the system at either the plant input or output. Specifically, while the step reference tracking problem can be reformulated as one of disturbance attenuation with a step disturbance at the plant output, the regulation problem corresponds to an impulse disturbance signal at the plant input.

We study these dual objective problems in both one-and twoparameter control schemes. Our primary motivation in this work is twofold. First, not only are the problems practically more relevant and generically more meaningful, but they in fact find rather pertinent applications in the design of mechanical systems; indeed, our investigation into the aforementioned tracking problem has been motivated by issues encountered in control of mechanical systems [10], [12]. It has been found in these studies that due to control energy constraint, which is typically required in mechanical systems, the system's performance may be restricted in rather different ways than predicted by the existing theory; for example, in some cases, the system's nonminimum phase behavior is no longer a dominant factor. Next, our investigation is also driven by a deeper goal, in hope of discovering control constraints and limitations beyond those already known. Specifically, under more realistic and thus more restrictive conditions allowable for control, would there exist other performance limitations than those imposed by nonminimum phase zeros, unstable poles, and time delays? We maintain that this question may receive an answer only when more practical performance goals are taken into consideration, specifically when conflicting design objectives are to be considered jointly; such is not the case with the standard tracking and regulation problems, nor will the answer be available from the Bode and Poisson integrals, or from the standard sensitivity and complementary sensitivity minimization problems [25], [13], [4]. In these problems, only a single, limiting control objective is considered.

While from a numerical standpoint the problems under study herein can all be solved using standard control methods and routines, our development yields analytical solutions. These analytical expressions are crucial for analyzing the limitations on the best achievable performance. Among other things, they show how the bandwidth of the plant may constrain the tracking accuracy when its input energy is finite. Control limitation due to the plant bandwidth is frequently encountered in practical designs, but rarely seems to have been characterized analytically. It is clear from our result that a constraint on the plant bandwidth will play a significant role in hampering tracking capability; the limitation exists whenever the plant input energy is kept finite, though it does vanish when the energy is allowed to be arbitrarily large. More generally, our results demonstrate in all cases how the best achievable performance may depend on the plant gain in the entire frequency range, and in particular help explain how lightly damped poles and antiresonant zeros in the plant may limit the achievable performance. The latter has a particularly close bearing on the control of mechanical systems, which typically exhibit lightly damped modes and anti-resonant zeros. The results thus unravel and quantify analytically yet another source of intrinsic feedback constraints. Needless to say, these constraints are consistent with one's intuition and exist in practical designs, though they may not be observed nor captured in theoretical, idealized control design problems, such as the aforementioned single-objective optimal control problems.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we define the notation and introduce the Youla parameterization of stabilizing controllers. We then proceed in Section III to formulate and solve the problem of optimal tracking under control effort constraint. This is done for plants that contain integrators but otherwise are stable, and with a one-parameter control structure; herein the presence of integral actions in the plant is necessary for the problem to be wellposed. The section also provides a brief narrative of allpass factorization of nonminimum phase transfer function matrices. Our development gives rise to a closed-form expression of the minimal achievable performance, which is seen to depend upon the plant nonminimum phase zeros as well as its gain at all frequencies, and which is further analyzed for its implications. A related constrained optimization problem is also investigated and a closed-form solution is obtained. Some numerical examples are provided which are shown to confirm the theoretical results. In Section IV, we state and develop parallel results for the optimal regulation problem with control effort consideration, using also one-parameter controllers. The results show similarly how the best performance may be constrained by the plant unstable poles, and by its gain. The roles of lightly damped poles and antiresonant zeros will then become clear. Extensions of these results are pursued in Section V, which investigates whether or not two-parameter controllers may improve the performance, thus ridding the performance of the effect due to the plant gain. It is shown nonetheless that two-parameter control cannot at all alter the performance limits fundamentally, especially that imposed by the plant gain. The paper concludes in Section VI.

However, a clear distinction exists between the tracking and the regulation problems. Indeed, unlike in the tracking problem, a large plant gain is seen to be undesirable for regulation. This does not come as a surprise, for a larger plant gain will necessarily amplify more the disturbance, making it more difficult to return the response to zero. Similarly, the lightly damped poles in the plant are now problematic factors. This too is consistent with one's intuition, since such poles tend to cause more unsettling response and thus require more control effort. Finally, Corollary 8 makes it clear that for regulation purpose a high plant bandwidth actually does more harm than benefit. This can be interpreted as the consequence that a system with a higher bandwidth responds at a faster speed, and it is more difficult to settle an "agile" response than a "sluggish" one.

div.head: V. TWO-PARAMETER CONTROL PERFORMANCE
div.p: Thus far our development has been restricted to tracking and regulation using a one-parameter controller, for marginally stable and minimum phase plants respectively. This section studies more general plants which may be both unstable and nonminimum phase. It is known that a two-parameter control structure is superior when tracking or regulation constitutes the sole design objective, specifically in countering the effect of plant unstable poles on tracking, and that of plant nonminimum phase zeros on regulation [6], [18]. The purpose of this section is to investigate whether it will also improve tracking and regulation performance when control effort is taken into consideration, and whether it may offer any advantage in circumventing the performance constraints imposed by the plant gain.

In summary, while two-parameter controllers do offer an distinctive advantage for tracking and regulation, their effect is limited to only nonminimum phase zeros, time delays, and unstable poles in the two respective problems. Theorems 4 and 5 make it clear that the dependence of the tracking and regulation performance on the plant gain remains unchanged, and so do the constraints due to plant bandwidth, lightly damped poles, and antiresonant zeros. Since two-parameter controllers constitute the most general linear feedback structure, these constraints are thus seen to pose a fundamental barrier to the achievable performance, and are intrinsic of the problems which both attempt to minimize the conflicting design objectives.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we have studied -type optimal tracking and regulation control problems, which attempt to minimize jointly the tracking error and plant input energy, and the output response along with input energy, respectively. These problems constitute an outgrowth of the classical optimal control problems, with a central goal focused on the role of control effort, an issue one invariably has to confront with in practical designs. Our primary objective has been to investigate the impact, if any, of control effort on the best achievable performance, and how such an impact may arise in a fundamental way independent of controller design and control structures. Our work is partly motivated by practical applications found in the control of mechanical systems, and partly driven by our goal in search of fundamental design limitations beyond those known to be imposed by nonminimum phase zeros, unstable poles, and time delays. For this purpose, we have derived analytical solutions to both problems, which describe explicitly how the best achievable performance may depend on the plant nonminimum phase zeros, time delays, unstable poles, and more importantly, on the plant frequency response as a whole. The results enable us to conclude that under finite control energy, the best tracking and regulation performance both depend on the plant gain in the entire frequency range, and as a result both can be significantly affected by the plant bandwidth. Furthermore, the results help clarify the roles of lightly damped poles and anti-resonant zeros, which have been seen to have a direct pertinence on the performance. That these constraints remain to be in effect in use of two-parameter controllers suggests that they result as a consequence of conflict and tradeoff between competing design objectives, while independent of controller design and control structures. In other words, no control structure may be employed to overcome these constraints. In contrast, in more idealistic settings where control effort is of no interest and thus excluded from the performance goal, the constraints vanish and thus find no role in the classical tracking and regulation problems.

The tracking and regulation problems being considered herein belong to the category of dual objective, two-block optimal control. In a more general setting, they may be viewed as two special instances of optimal disturbance attenuation problems, with disturbance inputs taken as step and impulse signals, respectively. Nevertheless, it is possible to extend the present results to more general disturbance attenuation problems. In the latter context, the input signals may assume more sophisticated forms, and the derivations as well as solutions would become proportionally more complicated. It is also possible to employ such tracking strategies as preview control [5], and it will be of interest to see whether the plant gain remains to play a significant role.
